unnormalised: I often get asked about yoga, and people mostly think it's all about twisting into pretzel shapes. That’s just one small part! My grandmother, Dadi, who lived till she was 95, always emphasized that yoga is a holistic approach to wellness. She started her day at 05:00 hrs every morning with pranayama on the banks of the Ganga in Varanasi, a habit she maintained until very late in life.

unnormalised: Yoga, as taught in places like the Bihar School of Yoga, Munger, extends far beyond asanas. It includes things like meditation (dhyana), breathing techniques (pranayama), ethical disciplines (yamas and niyamas), and even diet. Think of it as a comprehensive toolkit for a healthier, happier life.

unnormalised: I remember starting yoga seriously only after my knee injury in 2018. Before that, I thought it was too slow and boring! Now, I realize it's about connecting with your body and mind. It is a powerful tool to manage stress, improve flexibility and gain clarity of thought. I try to practice at least 3 times a week, focusing on different aspects each time.

unnormalised: One thing I wish more people understood is that yoga is not a competition. It's a personal journey. It’s about what works for you. On 26/01/2023, I learned a new breathing technique during a workshop in Rishikesh. It’s these small discoveries that keep me motivated. Even 15 minutes of mindful breathing can make a huge difference. It’s a tradition spanning thousands of years in India.
